body:
For a location, I think `transforations.series.date` is the right place.

Perhaps turn it into a folder to not have too much code in one `py` file, but keep the exports via `__init__` at the current location.

Thanks for creating this feature request.

-  Agreed, transformer should be generalized, allow for different aggregation levels and get a different name; e.g. temporal aggregator
- There are more challenges than mentioned so far;   
  -  frequency information is removed after TempAgg transform
      If I retain the information, the reconciler forecaster fails due to an internal check on frequencies.
     This is mitigated by recreating the indices in the inverse transform
  * Prediction is a bit weird due to this. You could argue that `predict([1,2])` gives a forecast for 14 days, i.e. two weeks.
  * The temporal aggregator now removes incomplete weeks, via a filter.
     It uses the days already known from the sales data in the final forecast in the inverse transform.
  * In the actual problem, I also have to account for closings. The shop is closed on some days and there are no sales.
    I aim to solve this by adding another transformer at the very end, which again does a disaggregation.
    Let me know if you have better ideas.

issue.title: [ENH] temporal aggregator

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Enables reconciliation at different temporal aggregation levels, e.g. weekly and daily
The level created needs to be of a lower sampling frequency. Only one higher level is supported.
So days can be resampled to weeks but not to weeks and months.
Forecasting starts from the last day of the last group, and not the last day.
To mitigate dates which are removed are placed back.

In the example below, airline times are loaded and relabelled to days.
A forecast is created at the weekly level and then converted back to days using historic disaggregation.


```python
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.transformations.hierarchical.aggregate import Aggregator
from sktime.transformations.series.date import TempAgg
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.reconcile import ReconcilerForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
import pandas as pd
weeks = 1
fh = 7*weeks
y = pd.DataFrame(load_airline())
y.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(pd.date_range(y.index.min().to_timestamp(),
                                          periods=len(y)))
# clip it
y=y[:y[y.index.weekday==6].index.max()]
y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=fh)

f = TempAgg(freq='W-MON')*Aggregator()*(TempAgg(freq='W-MON')**Aggregator()**ReconcilerForecaster(SARIMAX(), method='td_fcst'))
f.fit(y=y_train, X=y_train)
prds = f.predict(fh=list(range(1, weeks+1)), X=y_test)
```

#### Reference Issues/PRs
as suggested by @fkiraly in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3778

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

There are no tests at the moment. Only supports one level.
Forecasts start at date of latest grouping.
Incomplete groups are filters by getting median count.
This does not work for small datasets.
You have to ensure that your exogenous data consists out of complete groups.

#### Any other comments?

I will try to add support for multiple levels by the end of the week.
Probably, going to add support for passing a list and create aggregates by looping over it.

#### PR checklist

##### For all contributions
- [] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

body:
> If I retain the information, the reconciler forecaster fails due to an internal check on frequencies.
This is mitigated by recreating the indices in the inverse transform

Sounds pretty weird but not surprising, FYI @danbartl, @khrapovs, more `freq` arcana. Would be keen to see the failure example here.

> In the actual problem, I also have to account for closings. The shop is closed on some days and there are no sales.
I aim to solve this by adding another transformer at the very end, which again does a disaggregation.
Let me know if you have better ideas.

That works, another option would be date/time dummies or indicator variable creator.

We never got around to create the "holiday features transformer" that would follow this idea - so if you have some code hanging around somewhere ... would be much appreciated!

Here's the old feature request
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1675

> > If I retain the information, the reconciler forecaster fails due to an internal check on frequencies.
> > This is mitigated by recreating the indices in the inverse transform
> 
> Sounds pretty weird but not surprising, FYI @danbartl, @khrapovs, more `freq` arcana. Would be keen to see the failure example here.

See below a detailed failure, I digged a bit deeper and then ended up in with some freq issues.
To mitigate, I now simply remove all timestamps. 
```python
from sktime.transformations.base import BaseTransformer

class BugTempAgg(BaseTransformer):
    """TempAggregator which does not relabel indices fails
         look for ## FAIL CHANGES  to see where issue is created
    """

    _tags = {
        "scitype:transform-input": "Series",
        "scitype:transform-output": "pd_multiindex_hier",
        "scitype:transform-labels": "None",
        "fit_is_empty": False,
        "_output_convert": False,
        "scitype:instancewise": True,
        "X_inner_mtype": [
            "pd.Series",
            "pd.DataFrame",
            "pd-multiindex",
            "pd_multiindex_hier",
        ],
        "y_inner_mtype": "None",
        "capability:inverse_transform": False,
        "skip-inverse-transform": False,
        "univariate-only": False,
        "handles-missing-data": False,
        "X-y-must-have-same-index": False,
        "transform-returns-same-time-index": False,
    }

    def __init__(self, freq='W-MON', closed='left', label='left', level=0):
        super(BugTempAgg, self).__init__()
        self.freq = freq
        self.closed = closed
        self.label = label
        self.level = level

    def _helper(self, X_hat):
        """Filter series by only considering groups with median count."""
        grpsett = {'freq': self.freq,
                   'closed': self.closed,
                   'label': self.label,
                   'level': self.level}
        # calculate typical number of samples in group
        # to facilitate removal of incomplete groups
        # the sum is needed in the case you have
        # multilevel column index
        med_obsv = (X_hat.groupby(pd.Grouper(**grpsett))
                         .count()
                         .median()
                         .sum())
        X_hat = (X_hat.groupby([pd.Grouper(**grpsett)])
                      .filter(lambda x:
                              x.count().sum() == med_obsv))
        return X_hat, grpsett

    def _fit(self, X, y=None):
        """Fit transformer.

        Latest date seen is stored, so prediction continues
        from this date.
        Values which are removed due to grouping are stored
        so they can be reused.
        """
        X_hat = X.copy()
        self.index_name = X.index.name

        X_hat, _ = self._helper(X_hat)

        X_hat = (X_hat.groupby([pd.Grouper(level=0)])
                      .first())
        self.pred_date = (X_hat.index.max() +
                          (X_hat.index[1] - X_hat.index[0]))
        self.removed = X[self.pred_date:]
        # overwriting columns prevents duplication
        # in multilevel column dataframes
        self.columns = X.columns
        return self

    def _transform(self, X, y=None):
        X_hat = X.copy()
        X_hat, grpsett = self._helper(X_hat)
        ind_name = X.index.name
        grp_name = grpsett['freq']
        X_hat = (X_hat.groupby([pd.Grouper(**grpsett),
                               pd.Grouper(level=0)])
                      .first())
        X_hat.index.set_names([grp_name, ind_name],
                              inplace=True)
        grp_cnt = (X_hat.index
                        .get_level_values(grp_name)
                        .unique()
                        .size)
        # to_numpy needed for multi-level column dataframes
        ## FAIL CHANGES
        # ind_cnt = int((X_hat.groupby(pd.Grouper(**grpsett))
        #                    .count()
        #                    .median()
        #                    .to_numpy()[0]))
        # new_index = (pd.MultiIndex
        #               .from_product([range(grp_cnt), range(ind_cnt)],
        #                             names=[grp_name, ind_name]))
        # X_hat = (X_hat.set_index(new_index)
        ## END FAIL CHANGES
        X_hat = (X_hat.reorder_levels([ind_name, grp_name])
                      .sort_index(level=ind_name))
        return X_hat

    def inverse_transform(self, X, y=None):
        X_hat = X.copy()
        X_hat = (X_hat.groupby(level=[1, 0])
                      .first()
                      .reset_index(level=0,
                                   drop=True)
                      .drop(index=['__total'],
                            errors=['ignore']))
        X_hat.set_index(pd.date_range(self.pred_date,
                                      periods=len(X_hat)),
                        inplace=True)
        X_hat.columns = self.columns
        # replace if intersection
        intersec = (X_hat.index
                         .intersection(self.removed.index))
        if len(intersec) > 0:
            X_hat.loc[intersec] = self.removed.loc[intersec]

        self.pred_date = (pd.date_range(self.pred_date,
                                        periods=len(X_hat)+1)[-1])
        return X_hat
```
Code to make it fail
```python
import pandas as pd
from sktime.forecasting.reconcile import ReconcilerForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.sarimax import SARIMAX
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
y = pd.DataFrame(load_airline())
# get a day timestamp
y.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(pd.date_range(y.index.min().to_timestamp(),
                                         periods=len(y)))
f = (BugTempAgg(freq='W-MON')*ReconcilerForecaster(NaiveForecaster(),
      method='td_fcst'))#*TempAggRev())
f.fit(y=y)
f.predict([1,2])
```
Exception raised

@fkiraly thanks for your feedback. I am quite busy the coming days to show something to the business but will pick it up hereafter.
let me know if I can help. We have community collab sessions on Fridays if that could get some PR over the finish line.

Well, I was only able to find two new challenges.  
 - The Reconciliatior creates a forecast at levels (week and day) and then makes a prediction.
   As such, it requires way too much compute at scale. It doesn't use historic averages, but forecasts.
 - I can't update the pipe at the moment, it only allows fits. I run into a bug when I start updating my pipe.
    I am now trying to circumvent the reconciliation with a custom transformer.
